questions.question: He is fond …………………….. cricket.
questions.description: Certain adjectives are followed by ‘preposition + ing form’.

questions.question: ………………………… along the road, he found a dead cobra.
questions.description:
When we split the clauses we get: 
He was walking along the road
He found a dead cobra.
We can connect them with the present participle ‘walking’.

questions.question: We were prevented …………………………. the patient.
questions.description: The verb prevent is followed by 'preposition + ing form’.

questions.question: I hope you will excuse …………………………… leaving early.
questions.description: The word leaving is a gerund that serves the same purpose as a noun. We cannot use an object pronoun to modify a noun instead we use a possessive adjective (my).

questions.question: We rejoiced at ………………………….. being promoted.
questions.description: The word being is a gerund that serves the same purpose as a noun. We cannot use an object pronoun to modify a noun instead we use a possessive adjective (his).

questions.question: I insist on ………………………… being present at the meeting.
questions.description: The word being is a gerund that serves the same purpose as a noun. We cannot use an object pronoun to modify a noun instead we use a possessive adjective (your).

questions.question: We left without ……………………….. knowing.
questions.description: The word knowing is a gerund that serves the same purpose as a noun. We use a possessive expression to modify a noun.

questions.question: All depends on ………………………… passing the exam.
questions.description: The word passing is a gerund that serves the same purpose as a noun. We use a possessive expression to modify a noun.

questions.question: It ……………………… a very hot day, I remained in my tent.
questions.description: It was a very hot day. I remained in my tent. We can combine them with the participle being.

questions.question: …………………………… across the heath, a gipsy found the child.
questions.description:
A gypsy was wandering across the heath. He found the child. 
We can combine them with the present participle wandering.

questions.question: …………………………….. his lesson, he went out to play.
questions.description: He had learned his lesson. He went out to play. We can combine them with the perfect participle ‘having learned’.

questions.question: We met an old man …………………………….. to Jerusalem.
questions.description:
We met an old man. He was walking to Jerusalem.
We can combine the two clauses with the present participle ‘walking’.
